text:
CHUCK SHELTON: I think that
he can make a lot of changes.

I don't think he really
needs the headache
of being president.

JANE WILSON: I think the
country needed a big change

and he was not a politician,
he was a businessman.

ROBERT HILDEBRAND: I think he's
doing everything that he can.
One man can only do so much.
I think he's doing a good job.

JANE WILSON: I voted
for Donald Trump.

CHUCK SHELTON: I
voted for Trump.

ROBERT HILDEBRAND: I
voted for Donald Trump.

WILL RICHARDS: I
felt like he was

going to give us a good
opportunity to build business.
He was favorable towards coal.

JANE WILSON: I think he
can do an intervention

either through the government
or through the EPA.

There's got to be some way
out there for him to intervene

to extend it so
that there is time
for people to prepare for this.

CHUCK SHELTON: I would like to
see Trump get with our governor

and deal with the
emissions and also

get with the owners
of our plan about

instead of shutting it down
maybe putting it up for sale.

WILL RICHARDS: I'd be able to
keep my job where I currently

work at and I'd be able
to provide for my family

and wouldn't have
the burden on my back

right now of trying
to figure out

what I'm going to do
in a year and a half
when the plant closes.

JANE WILSON: If he
can't stop this,

Manchester will probably
become a very, very small
footprint of what it is now.

WILL RICHARDS: You'll see people
that will stop making their car

payment, stop making their house
payment, start hitting the bars
and getting drunk and drugs.

And it's just going
to be a domino effect.

ROBERT HILDEBRAND:
President Trump,

come down here and tour the area
to see what it does mean to us.

CHUCK SHELTON: Please look
into saving these power plants

and saving all these people's
jobs, communities, the
contractors, small businesses.

Everything around here is just
going to be totally devastated
and it's going to be really bad.

WILL RICHARDS: We
need your help.
